title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: Main U.S. funder of physical sciences chops down advisory panels, alarms researchers
items.description: Scientists fear merger of Department of Energy advisory committees that gave them their voices at agency

items.title: Forests are migrating up mountain peaks
items.description: Satellite imagery reveals an unexpected shift in tree lines—but it may not have anything to do with climate change

items.title: Australia’s red rocks hold mysteriously detailed fossils. We finally know how they formed
items.description: Chemical analysis could help predict locations of other ancient sites with impeccable fossils

items.title: Startup pioneers subscription service for space-based astronomy
items.description: Blue Skies Space will sell data from its tiny, low-cost UV telescope

items.title: <cite>Science</cite>’s ‘Dance Your Ph.D.’ contest is open again—with an all new, AI twist
items.description: For the first time, there’s a special prize for a research-themed dance generated by an artificial intelligence program

items.title: Letters to scientific journals surge as ‘prolific debutante’ authors likely use AI
items.description: New study reinforces worries about “mass production of junk” by unscrupulous scholars aiming to pad their CVs

items.title: This organism turns dino bones orange—making them easier to spot
items.description: Paleontologists use drones and brightly colored lichen to search for fossils in the Canadian Badlands

items.title: Antarctic glacier shows fastest retreat in modern history
items.description: Tides and glacial earthquakes caused record ice loss at Hektoria Glacier

items.title: A flood of Chinese graduate students in STEM was a boon to U.S. students
items.description: Study shows the influx allowed U.S. programs to expand enrollment and also benefited local businesses

items.title: Egypt joins Europe’s flagship science program, raising academic freedom concerns
items.description: Horizon Europe’s push for free inquiry clashes with Egypt’s human rights record, critics say
